title: Sinner's Resilient Advance to Australian Open Quarter-Finals Amid Physical Adversity
summary: Jannik Sinner, the reigning Australian Open champion, showcased a revitalized demeanor as he secured a place in the quarter-finals with a commanding 6-1, 6-3, 7-6 (7-2) victory over compatriot Luciano Darderi. This performance followed a grueling third-round encounter where Sinner endured 40Â°C heat and cramping, narrowly avoiding an upset by world number 85 Eliot Spizzirri, aided by the closure of the roof. Against an injury-hampered Darderi, Sinner exhibited enhanced vigor, swiftly claiming the first two sets with minimal resistance, though signs of fatigue emerged in the third set as Darderi mounted a comeback to force a tie-break. Sinner's ability to elevate his game under pressure culminated in his 18th consecutive triumph at Melbourne Park. In post-match remarks, he acknowledged the match's difficulty and his relief at a three-set conclusion, emphasizing their off-court friendship. Looking ahead, Sinner faces either Ben Shelton or Casper Ruud, with the historic objective of becoming only the second man, after Novak Djokovic, to achieve three successive Australian Open titles. This narrative underscores Sinner's strategic adaptability and psychological fortitude in elite tennis.
